title: Did black people create rock and roll? - Quora

response.answer_text:
Great answers. Yes, blacks created rock and roll, but the original stuff was too raw for White sensibilities and had to be sanitized. I thought I would pick a dog theme for illustration—3 tunes from the Fifties. The first is “How Much is that Doggie in the Window?” by Patti Page. It topped the charts in 1953. This is what White America was used to hearing. Meanwhile, the black community was doing “race music.” An example is “Hound Dog,” by Mama Thorton, 1952. It was about a deadbeat guy who was always hanging around, trying to freeload off her. Typical blues theme, but totally unacceptable for Normal Rockwell’s America. See the version by Elvis Presley below that, which became a number one hit. “How Much is that Doggie in the Window?”— Patti Page, 1953  Big Mama Thornton – Hound Dog HOUND DOG LYRICS, 1952 [Chorus]You ain't nothing but a hound dogBeen snoopin' 'round my doorYou ain't nothing but a hound dogBeen snoopin' 'round my doorYou can wag your tail
But I ain't gonna feed you no more [Verse 1]You told me you was high classBut I could see through thatShe told me you was high classBut I could see through thatAnd daddy I know
You ain't no real cool cat [Chorus]You ain't nothing but a hound dogBeen snoopin' 'round my doorYou ain't nothing but a hound dogBeen snoopin' 'round my doorYou can wag your tail
But I ain't gonna feed you no more [Verse 2]You made me feel so blueYou made me weep and moanYou made me feel so blueYou made me weep and moanCause you ain't looking for a womanAll you're lookin' is for a home [Chorus]You ain't nothing but a hound dogBeen snoopin' 'round my doorYou ain't nothing but a hound dogBeen snoopin' 'round my doorYou can wag your tail
But I ain't gonna feed you no more Elvis Presley – Hound Dog HOUND DOG LYRICS, 1956 [Chorus]You ain't nothing but a hound dogCrying all the timeYou ain't nothing but a hound dog
Crying all the timeWell, you ain't never caught a rabbit
And you ain't no friend of mine [Verse]When they said you was high classed
Well, that was just a lieYeah, they said you was high classedWell, that was just a lieYeah, you ain't never caught a rabbit
And you ain't no friend of mine [Chorus]You ain't nothing but a hound dogCrying all the timeYou ain't nothing but a hound dog
Crying all the timeWell, you ain't never caught a rabbit
And you ain't no friend of mine [Bridge]Ahh, ahhAhh, ahh [Verse]When they said you was high classed
Well, that was just a lieYeah, they said you was high classedWell, that was just a lieWell, you ain't never caught a rabbit
And you ain't no friend of mine [Bridge]Ahh, ahhAhh, ahh [Verse]When they said you was high classed
Well, that was just a lieYou know, they said you was high classedWell, that was just a lieYeah, you ain't never caught a rabbit
And you ain't no friend of mine [Chorus]You ain't nothing but a hound dogCrying all the timeYou ain't nothing but a hound dog
Crying all the timeWell, you ain't never caught a rabbit
You ain't no friend of mine

Yes. “Rock and Roll” was African-American Slang for Sex in the early 1900s. All original Americans styles of music except for Bluegrass originates form West African and was created by African Americans. African songs became Slave Spirituals, these Spirituals became Gospel music, Gospel music branched into Jazz, Blues, R&B, and Soul. Rock and Roll is a combination of All of the genres mentioned before. Earlier Rock and Roll acts were called “Race music. African-American music - Wikipedia  One of the legacies of racism in America is the desire to down play achievements related to African people. One of the reasons Elvis is coined “The King of Rock and Roll” is because he was a White man doing the same type of music but its not coming from a people the audience were told to hate and distrust. Also the fact that some Black teens were becoming heartthrobs didn’t sit well with most White parents of that time period.

Certainly black artists created the core which was the first Rock N´ Roll but then white artists created pop-rock, hard rock, metal, punk, grunge and all the rest of the subgenres. Elvis Presley, The Beatles, AC/DC, David Bowie, Queen and others were much better and influenced much more with better rock. Even Carlos Santana(Mexican) created Latin Rock, and the rest of the world created their own rock forms. Rock is not one thing that was invented once, it´s a genre that has been developing and innovating through the years around the world.

Bill Hayley was one of the First Rock n Roll artists of the 1950s then Little Richard and Chuck Berry along with Jerry Lee Lewis, some one the American music those days was actually Rhythm and Blues like Fats Domino but Elvis was mostly Rock n Roll in his early days, Buddy Holly started off as RockaBilly and he then created his own unique style that a lot of Early 1960s English bands got their inspirations from..people in Britain do not call it Rock n Roll but Rock music instead as of our band's in the 1960s like Cream and Led Zeppelin and we associate Rock n Roll with artists from the 1950s from the USA.

Mostly yes I’d say, tho not wholly. Here’s a quickie answer, not a definitive one. It’s largely based on West African Music, Negro Spirituals, and slightly later the Delta Blues … all originally black folks’ music … but it’s also partly based on ‘country-western’ music, which has its origins in bluegrass and other ‘hillbilly music’ of the Scotch-Irish of Appalachia and the lowlands adjacent to it.

Long story short, Yes. The roots go back to the late 1800’s, through some very odd roads including Delta Blues, Gospel, Western Swing , Jazz……but eventually everything leads up to Chuck Berry codifying the Rock and Roll canon for guitar playing and songwriting.
Rosette Tharpe invented the sound. Meet Sister Rosetta Tharpe, the black woman who invented that rock and roll sound
That depends, both Elvis and Chuck Berry played a synthesis of blues and country. But most ‘modern’ white rock ’n’ roll is firmly rooted in black boogie.
yes. as i see it. rock and roll evolved from the Blues— no doubt. Arthur “Big Boy” Crudup. good place to start. “That’s all right Mama”—- but it goes way back from there—
